section.title: Velocity
section.p: Motion is frequently modeled using calculus. A building block for this application is the concept of average velocity. Average velocity is defined to be net displacement divided by elapsed time. More precisely,

statement.p: If p is a position function for something moving along a numbered line, then we define the average velocity over the time interval \cinterval{t_0}{t_1} to be: \text{average velocity}=\frac{\fe{p}{t_1}-\fe{p}{t_0}}{t_1-t_0}\text{.}

introduction.p: According to simplified Newtonian physics, if an object is dropped from an elevation of 200 and allowed to free fall to the ground, then the elevation of the object (measured in ) is given by the position function \fe{p}{t}=200-4.9t^2 where t is the amount of time that has passed since the object was dropped (measured in ).
